line: Orchestration of Robotic Activities in
label: heading

line: Classrooms: Challenges and Opportunities
label: heading

line: Sina Shahmoradi1, Jennifer K. Olsen1, Stian Haklev1, Wafa Johal1,2, Utku
label: paragraph

line: Norman1, Jauwairia Nasir1, and Pierre Dillenbourg1
label: paragraph

line: 1 Computer-Human Interaction in Learning and Instruction (CHILI) Laboratory,
label: paragraph

line: EPFL, Switzerland
label: paragraph

line: 2 Biorobotics Laboratory (BioRob), EPFL, Switzerland
label: paragraph

line: Abstract. Bringing robots into classrooms presents a new set of chal-
label: paragraph

line: lenges for classroom management and teacher support compared to tradi-
label: paragraph

line: tional technology-enhanced learning and has been left almost unexplored
label: paragraph

line: by the research community. In this paper, we present the opportunities
label: paragraph

line: and challenges of orchestrating Educational Robotics (ER) activities in
label: paragraph

line: classrooms. To support our discussion, we present a case study of 25
label: paragraph

line: students working in pairs using handheld robots to engage in a compu-
label: paragraph

line: tational thinking activity. While performing the activity, students’ be-
label: paragraph

line: havioral information was sent from the robots to an orchestration dash-
label: paragraph

line: board that was used in a debrieﬁng activity. Although this work is in its
label: paragraph

line: preliminary stages, it contributes to framing the challenges that need to
label: paragraph

line: be addressed to realistically scale-up usage of ER in classrooms.
label: paragraph

line: Keywords: Classroom Orchestration · Educational Robotics
label: paragraph

line: 1 Introduction
label: heading

line: The main pedagogical advantage of learning activities with Educational Robotics
label: paragraph

line: (ER) is to facilitate constructivism activities, which gives the active role to stu-
label: paragraph

line: dents [1]. An open question in ER research is whether robots would be viable op-
label: paragraph

line: tions for supporting learning in ecologically valid classroom environments [1]. To
label: paragraph

line: answer this question, we must consider what role the teacher plays with the use
label: paragraph

line: of robots in the classroom and the impact it has on classroom orchestration [3].
label: paragraph

line: Classroom management, even in traditional classes, is a complex problem and
label: paragraph

line: adding multiple robots to learning activities creates new management challenges
label: paragraph

line: for teachers. There have been a few studies that presented awareness tools for
label: paragraph

line: ER activities, for instance by classifying students progress in an ER activity [4].
label: paragraph

line: In this work, the main challenge addressed is to face the unpredictable nature
label: paragraph

line: of ER learning activities, which makes it hard for teachers to follow students
label: paragraph

line: work and may make teachers’ interventions harder than in other TEL class-
label: paragraph

line: rooms. Furthermore, the added complexity of robots increases the frequency of
label: paragraph

line: interventions for technical failures. However, these studies have not been mainly
label: paragraph

line: conducted around the core idea of orchestration, which is minimalist, teacher-
label: paragraph

line: centric deign [3]. Additionally, there is no concrete study in the literature that
label: paragraph

line: 2 S. Shahmoradi et al.
label: paragraph

line: investigates ER classrooms from an orchestrational perspective, which is an es-
label: paragraph

line: sential step to design orchestration technologies. As the preliminary step of our
label: paragraph

line: work, in this paper, we present the ﬁndings around observations from a case
label: paragraph

line: study of running an ER session with two main goals: 1) what problems would
label: paragraph

line: teachers encounter in conducting ER activities? and 2) what do teachers need in
label: paragraph

line: terms of technology for conducting such activities? These ﬁnding pave the way
label: paragraph

line: through designing orchestration technologies for ER classrooms.
label: paragraph

line: 2 Study Context
label: heading

line: We conducted a preliminary study with 25 students, 11-12 years old and novice
label: paragraph

line: users with our robot, working in pairs (do to the quantity of available robots), on
label: paragraph

line: a computational thinking task in an hour long session. For the primary learning
label: paragraph

line: activity, which lasted thirty minutes, the students were asked to use a handheld,
label: paragraph

line: low-cost, tangible robot, Cellulo [5] to explore diﬀerent paths on a paper map
label: paragraph

line: to ﬁnd the optimal path, see Fig. 1a. Before the main activity, they had enough
label: paragraph

line: time to experience using the robots. During the activity, the students received
label: paragraph

line: feedback from the robot through LED lights that indicated the level of pretend
label: paragraph

line: battery, which depleted as the robot is moved on a route. During this activity,
label: paragraph

line: we collected the position of the robot on the map and remaining battery level
label: paragraph

line: to measure the exploration behavior of the students. More details about the
label: paragraph

line: experimental settings is available online3.
label: paragraph

line: After the path-ﬁnding activity, the students were given two short quizzes to
label: paragraph

line: assess their knowledge, one individual and one collaborative, before participating
label: paragraph

line: in a whole class debrieﬁng activity. For the debrieﬁng activity, a preliminary
label: paragraph

line: version of a dashboard was used that displayed the number of exploration trials
label: paragraph

line: (that robot is moved from home to target) that each team completed and battery
label: paragraph

line: level at target. During the debrieﬁng, a member of the research team led a whole
label: paragraph

line: class session with the students to discuss these results and explained how the
label: paragraph

line: path-ﬁnding activity was tied to the concepts they were trying to learn, see
label: paragraph

line: Fig. 1b. Throughout the study, four experimenters conducted the activity and
label: paragraph

line: took ﬁeld notes pertaining to the classroom orchestration. After the experiment,
label: paragraph

line: the research team discussed their observations to ﬁnd common themes.
label: paragraph

line: 3 Challenges and Opportunities
label: heading

line: We begin this section by evaluating the preliminary version of the dashboard
label: paragraph

line: used in the debrieﬁng activity. Based on experimenters’ observations, students
label: paragraph

line: were very engaged in observing their own behaviours and the review helped
label: paragraph

line: them to understand the learning goal of the activity. Experimenters suggested
label: paragraph

line: that using data from an ER activity in a subsequent debrieﬁng activity and
label: paragraph

line: functionalities of making data ﬂow between ER activities and other activities in
label: paragraph

line: the classroom can be very useful for teachers. For example, a teacher can use
label: paragraph

line: 3 https://github.com/chili-epfl/robot-analytics
label: paragraph

line: Orchestration of Robotic Activities in Classrooms 3
label: paragraph

line: (a) Cellulo robot and a paper map (b) Debrieﬁng activity
label: paragraph

line: Fig.1: An overview of the ER activity: a) Children working on the path-ﬁnding activity with a Cellulo
label: paragraph

line: robot in pairs b) Using an orchestration dashboard monitoring robot sensory data in a debrieﬁng
label: paragraph

line: activity to explain learning goals and discuss children’s performance
label: paragraph

line: students’ activity data as an example to prove a point in his/her lecture or show
label: paragraph

line: the classroom performance on a central screen during an ER activity to increase
label: paragraph

line: competition between groups. In the continue of this section, the experimenters’
label: paragraph

line: notes and discussions around them are summarized as four points:
label: paragraph

line: Managing robot technical failures: All the experimenters insisted the emer-
label: paragraph

line: gence for monitoring the technical status of robots. In our case study, although
label: paragraph

line: the technical system had an overall acceptable performance, three robots failed
label: paragraph

line: during the activity and required intervention. In a classroom with one teacher
label: paragraph

line: rather than four experimenters, it could take some time for the teacher to be
label: paragraph

line: notiﬁed about the problem, which is not eﬃcient time management. This case
label: paragraph

line: happened for us since the robot technical failures were hard to diagnose for
label: paragraph

line: experimenters during the session.
label: paragraph

line: Teacher control over robotic activities: Experimenters mentioned their inter-
label: paragraph

line: ests to be able to control robots for fostering the meta-cognitive skills of the
label: paragraph

line: students, such as through changing the diﬃculty level of an activity or inhibit-
label: paragraph

line: ing the running of robots to regulate learners’ reﬂection and stopping them from
label: paragraph

line: playing too much with the robot, which is one of the challenges with open-ended
label: paragraph

line: ER activities [2]. The latter could be achieved by providing simple orchestration
label: paragraph

line: commands over robots, like pausing them.
label: paragraph

line: Managing collaboration in ER group activities: Due to the cost of educational
label: paragraph

line: robots, in the group activities, one robot is shared between group members,
label: paragraph

line: which could lead to social loaﬁng as we also observed in our case study. Although
label: paragraph

line: this problem is not speciﬁc to ER classes, the interaction patterns that students
label: paragraph

line: have during the activity are diﬀerent than traditional collaborative activities
label: paragraph

line: and the awareness and interventions need to be designed diﬀerently. An open
label: paragraph

line: question that arose from the experimenters’ notes was: how can students’ activity
label: paragraph

line: data with robots be used to raise teachers’ awareness about social loaﬁng and
label: paragraph

line: how can teachers intervene using control over robots to solve the problem?
label: paragraph

line: 4 S. Shahmoradi et al.
label: paragraph

line: Improving teachers’ distributed awareness: Experimenters mentioned several
label: paragraph

line: features of robots that can enhance teacher awareness: 1) in contrast to tablets
label: paragraph

line: or laptop screens, robots materialize learners’ activity and collaboration patterns
label: paragraph

line: in groups on tables, giving the activity more visibility. 2) In learning tasks that
label: paragraph

line: require student interactions with both tablets and robots, like programming a
label: paragraph

line: robot, working with a robot reiﬁes what is happening in the screen for teach-
label: paragraph

line: ers to see. In other words, instead of going to each group’s desk and checking
label: paragraph

line: whether they ﬁnished the activity or cluttering the teacher dashboard with more
label: paragraph

line: information, teachers can easily understand the class performance by having a
label: paragraph

line: glance at all robots in the classroom, which is not possible with laptops/tablets.
label: paragraph

line: 4 Conclusion and Future Works
label: heading

line: Taking into account the ﬁndings from observing our case study in the third sec-
label: paragraph

line: tion, we propose the following features in orchestrating tools for ER classrooms:
label: paragraph

line: The teacher dashboard should aware teachers about 1) robot technical status to
label: paragraph

line: notify teachers about technical problems and 2) students’ interaction patterns
label: paragraph

line: with robots to represent students’ progress and collaboration behaviour. Also,
label: paragraph

line: orchestrating tools should provide 1) teacher control over robots for interven-
label: paragraph

line: tions like meta-cognitive support for encouraging reﬂection and 2) aggregating
label: paragraph

line: students’ activity data with robots in teachers’ lectures and debrieﬁng activities
label: paragraph

line: regarding our observation of implementing such a system. In the way of designing
label: paragraph

line: orchestration tools with the mentioned functionalities for ER classrooms, there
label: paragraph

line: are still important open questions such as: what type of information from stu-
label: paragraph

line: dents’ activities with robots is useful for teachers, and considering the mentioned
label: paragraph

line: potentials of robots in providing awareness in classroom, can they be utilized as
label: paragraph

line: distributed orchestration tools instead of orchestrable tools? We believe that an-
label: paragraph

line: swering these questions will create new insights to research on both educational
label: paragraph

line: robotics and orchestrating technology-enhanced learning.
label: paragraph
